name: Tomato Hornworm
description: Large green caterpillar (3-4 inches) with white V-shaped markings and a horn on the rear. Larva of the five-spotted hawk moth. Feeds voraciously and can strip a plant overnight.
symptoms: Defoliated stems, large irregular holes in leaves, dark green/black droppings on foliage below, chewed fruit, bare stems with only midribs remaining
organicTreatments: Companion plant with dill to attract parasitic wasps
preventionTips: Rotate nightshade crops
Till soil in fall to destroy pupae
Plant dill and parsley to attract braconid wasps
Check plants daily in early morning

name: Aphids
description: Tiny (1-3mm) soft-bodied, pear-shaped insects in green, black, red, or yellow. Cluster on new growth, leaf undersides, and flower buds. Reproduce rapidly and can colonize plants in days.
symptoms: Curled or distorted new leaves, sticky honeydew residue on foliage, black sooty mold growth, stunted growth, yellowing leaves, clusters of small insects on stems and leaf undersides
organicTreatments: Strong blast of water from hose
preventionTips: Encourage beneficial insects with companion planting
Avoid excess nitrogen fertilization
Plant nasturtium as a trap crop
Inspect transplants before planting
Use reflective mulch to disorient aphids

name: Cabbage Worm
description: Velvety green caterpillar (about 1 inch) that is the larva of the white cabbage butterfly. The adult is a common white butterfly with black wing tips frequently seen in gardens.
symptoms: Large ragged holes in leaves, green frass on leaves and in leaf folds, damaged heads with bore holes, skeletonized leaves in severe infestations
organicTreatments: Row covers to exclude adult butterflies
preventionTips: Use floating row covers from transplanting
Plant red or purple cabbage varieties which are less attractive
Interplant with thyme and sage to deter adults
Inspect undersides of leaves for yellow eggs

name: Squash Vine Borer
description: A clearwing moth larva that bores into squash stems at the base. The adult moth is orange and black, resembling a wasp, and lays flat brown eggs on stems near soil level.
symptoms: Sudden wilting of entire vine despite adequate water, sawdust-like frass at base of stems, mushy stem near soil line, entry holes visible at stem base
organicTreatments: Surgical removal with razor blade and BT injection into stem
Wrap stem base with aluminum foil or nylon stocking
Inject BT into stem near base
Succession planting after moth flight period
preventionTips: Cover plants with row covers until flowering
Plant resistant varieties like butternut squash
Wrap lower stems with aluminum foil preventatively
Till soil in fall to expose overwintering pupae
Delay planting until after peak moth activity

name: Colorado Potato Beetle
description: Round, yellow-orange beetle (3/8 inch) with 10 black stripes on its wing covers. Larvae are reddish-orange with black spots along their sides. Both adults and larvae are heavy feeders.
symptoms: Skeletonized leaves, complete defoliation in severe cases, clusters of bright orange-yellow eggs on leaf undersides, reduced tuber yield
organicTreatments: Handpicking adults, larvae, and egg masses
preventionTips: Rotate nightshade crops annually
Use thick straw mulch to impede adult emergence
Plant early maturing varieties
Grow trap crops of eggplant to lure beetles away
Till soil in fall to expose overwintering adults

name: Japanese Beetle
description: Metallic green and copper-colored beetle (1/2 inch) with white tufts of hair along abdomen sides. Adults skeletonize leaves while grubs feed on grass roots underground.
symptoms: Skeletonized leaves with only veins remaining, damaged flowers and fruit, brown patches in lawn from grub feeding on roots
organicTreatments: Handpicking into soapy water (most effective in early morning)
Neem oil spray to deter feeding
Milky spore or beneficial nematodes for grub control in lawn
Row covers during peak beetle season
preventionTips: Apply milky spore disease to lawn for long-term grub control
Avoid Japanese beetle traps near garden (they attract more beetles)
Plant less-preferred crops or resistant varieties
Keep garden well-weeded as beetles prefer stressed plants

name: Flea Beetles
description: Tiny (1/16 to 1/8 inch) dark-colored jumping beetles that leap when disturbed. Several species target different crops. Named for their flea-like hopping behavior.
symptoms: Numerous small round holes or pits in leaves giving a shothole appearance, stunted seedlings, wilting of young transplants, damage worst on cotyledon and first true leaves
preventionTips: Use floating row covers on seedlings
Delay planting brassicas until plants are larger and more tolerant
Maintain healthy soil to support vigorous growth
Interplant with catnip or basil
Remove crop debris in fall

name: Cucumber Beetle (Striped)
description: Small (1/4 inch) yellowish-green beetle with three black stripes on wing covers. Transmits bacterial wilt disease. Larvae feed on roots and stems below soil.
symptoms: Chewed holes in leaves, flowers, and fruit rind, scarred fruit, wilting from bacterial wilt transmission, stunted seedlings, damaged roots from larval feeding
preventionTips: Use floating row covers until plants begin flowering
Plant resistant varieties
Delay planting until plants are well-established
Interplant with radish and tansy
Remove and destroy crop debris after harvest

name: Whiteflies
description: Tiny (1/16 inch) white-winged insects that fly up in clouds when plants are disturbed. Found on leaf undersides where they feed on plant sap. Related to aphids and scale insects.
symptoms: Yellowing leaves, sticky honeydew on leaves, black sooty mold, stunted growth, leaf drop, white cloud of tiny insects when plants are disturbed
preventionTips: Inspect transplants before bringing into garden
Use reflective mulch around plants
Encourage natural enemies
Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilizer
Remove heavily infested plants promptly

name: Spider Mites
description: Microscopic (1/50 inch) eight-legged arachnids, usually red or yellowish. Thrive in hot, dry conditions. Populations can explode rapidly, doubling every few days in warm weather.
symptoms: Fine stippling or speckling on leaves, tiny webbing on leaf undersides and between branches, yellowing and bronzing of leaves, leaf drop, dusty appearance on foliage
organicTreatments: Strong blast of water to undersides of leaves
preventionTips: Keep plants well-watered (mites prefer dry conditions)
Avoid broad-spectrum insecticides that kill predators
Mist plants during hot dry spells
Keep garden free of dusty conditions
Remove heavily infested leaves

name: Slugs and Snails
description: Soft-bodied mollusks that feed primarily at night and in wet conditions. Slugs lack shells while snails carry coiled shells. Leave characteristic silvery slime trails on plants and soil.
symptoms: Large irregular holes in leaves (especially between veins), slime trails on plants and soil, seedlings eaten to ground level, holes in fruit resting on ground
organicTreatments: Handpicking at night with a flashlight
preventionTips: Water in the morning so soil is drier at night
Remove debris and hiding spots near beds
Use drip irrigation instead of overhead watering
Encourage ground beetles and birds
Raise containers off ground

name: Cutworms
description: Plump, smooth caterpillars (1-2 inches) that curl into a C-shape when disturbed. Usually gray, brown, or black. Larvae of various noctuid moths. Feed at night and hide in soil by day.
symptoms: Seedlings cut off cleanly at or just below soil surface, young transplants toppled overnight, missing seedlings, chewed leaves near ground level
organicTreatments: Cardboard or foil collars around transplant stems
Handpicking at night with a flashlight
preventionTips: Place cardboard collars (toilet paper rolls) around transplants
Clear debris and weeds before planting
Till soil in fall to expose larvae
Delay transplanting until stems are thicker
Keep garden well-weeded

name: Corn Earworm
description: Variable-colored caterpillar (1-2 inches) ranging from green to brown to pink with light stripes. Also called tomato fruitworm and cotton bollworm. Enters corn ears through the silk channel.
symptoms: Chewed kernels at tip of corn ears, frass and silk damage at ear tips, bore holes in tomato and pepper fruit, feeding damage to lettuce heads
organicTreatments: Apply mineral oil to corn silks after pollination
Clip ear tips after harvest to remove larvae
preventionTips: Plant corn varieties with tight husks
Time plantings to avoid peak moth flights
Apply 5 drops of mineral oil to silk tips just as silks begin to brown
Remove and destroy infested ears promptly
Till soil after harvest

name: Squash Bug
description: Flat, shield-shaped, dark brown to grayish-black bug (5/8 inch). Adults overwinter and emerge in spring. Nymphs are smaller and lighter colored with reddish legs and head.
symptoms: Wilting leaves that turn crispy and black, yellow speckling on leaves, plant collapse, clusters of bronze-colored eggs on leaf undersides, foul odor when crushed
organicTreatments: Trap boards (place boards near plants, collect hiding bugs in morning)
Insecticidal soap on young nymphs only
preventionTips: Remove crop debris in fall where adults overwinter
Use row covers until flowering
Plant resistant varieties like butternut squash
Check leaf undersides for egg clusters regularly
Interplant with nasturtium and tansy

name: Mexican Bean Beetle
description: Copper-colored, round beetle (1/4 inch) with 16 black spots on wing covers. Often mistaken for a ladybug. Yellow, spiny larvae feed on leaf undersides. Both stages are damaging.
symptoms: Skeletonized leaves with lacy appearance, chewed pods, yellow spiny larvae on leaf undersides, reduced plant vigor, defoliation in severe infestations
preventionTips: Remove and destroy crop debris immediately after harvest
Rotate bean plantings
Plant early-maturing varieties to avoid peak populations
Interplant with rosemary and marigold
Avoid planting near alfalfa or clover

name: Carrot Rust Fly
description: Small (1/4 inch) shiny black fly with an orange head and yellow legs. Larvae are cream-colored maggots that tunnel into carrot roots. Two generations per year in most areas.
symptoms: Rusty brown tunnels in carrot roots, forked or distorted roots, wilting foliage, secondary rot in damaged roots, rusty frass near root surface
organicTreatments: Row covers to exclude adult flies
Delayed planting to avoid first generation
preventionTips: Cover carrots with fine mesh row covers from sowing to harvest
Time plantings to avoid peak fly activity (May-June, August-September)
Interplant with alliums (onion, garlic, leek) to mask carrot scent
Rotate carrot family crops
Avoid thinning carrots in evening when flies are active

name: Harlequin Bug
description: Shield-shaped stink bug (3/8 inch) with striking red/orange and black markings. Feeds by piercing plant tissue and sucking sap. Most damaging in southern regions.
symptoms: White or yellow blotchy spots on leaves where sap has been drained, wilting and browning of leaves, stunted or killed plants, barrel-shaped black and white striped eggs in neat rows
organicTreatments: Handpicking adults and destroying egg masses
Trap crops of mustard or turnip
preventionTips: Plant trap crops of early mustard to lure bugs away
Remove crop debris in fall
Till soil in spring to disrupt overwintering
Inspect transplants for egg masses
Keep garden weed-free, especially brassica weeds

name: Thrips
description: Extremely tiny (1/25 inch) slender insects, usually tan, brown, or black. Rasp plant surfaces and suck the released juices. Often found inside flowers and between leaf sheaths.
symptoms: Silvery or bronze streaking on leaves, distorted or scarred flowers and fruit, black fecal specks on leaves, stunted growth, papery white patches on leaf surfaces
preventionTips: Remove weeds and grass around garden that harbor thrips
Use reflective aluminum mulch
Avoid over-fertilizing with nitrogen
Spray plants with water regularly
Remove and destroy infested plant material

name: Root-Knot Nematodes
description: Microscopic roundworms that invade plant roots, causing characteristic knots or galls. Multiple species affect different crops. Most active in warm, sandy soils. Cannot be seen without magnification.
symptoms: Stunted growth with no apparent cause, wilting during warm days despite adequate water, yellowing and nutrient deficiency symptoms, knobby swollen galls on roots visible at harvest
organicTreatments: Plant French marigolds as a cover crop to reduce populations
Incorporate mustard meal or rapeseed meal into soil
preventionTips: Rotate susceptible crops with resistant ones
Plant French marigolds extensively (they suppress nematodes)
Add generous compost to support beneficial soil organisms
Solarize soil before planting in heavily infested areas
Choose nematode-resistant varieties (look for N on seed packets)

name: Leaf Miners
description: Larvae (maggots) of small flies that tunnel between the upper and lower surfaces of leaves, creating visible winding trails. Several species target different plant families.
symptoms: Winding white or tan trails (mines) visible in leaves, blotch-shaped mines in some species, small puncture marks from adult feeding, reduced photosynthesis, premature leaf drop
organicTreatments: Row covers to exclude adult flies
Neem oil spray to deter egg-laying
preventionTips: Use row covers to prevent adult flies from laying eggs
Remove and compost affected leaves promptly
Attract parasitic wasps with dill, parsley, and yarrow
Clean up crop debris at end of season
Avoid broad-spectrum insecticides

name: Early Blight
description: A common fungal disease (Alternaria solani) affecting tomatoes and potatoes. Favored by warm temperatures (75-85°F), high humidity, and frequent rainfall. Overwinters in soil and plant debris.
symptoms: Dark brown concentric ring spots (target-like) on lower leaves first, yellowing around spots, progressive defoliation from bottom up, dark sunken lesions on stems and fruit, premature fruit drop
organicTreatments: Remove and destroy infected leaves promptly
Baking soda spray (1 tbsp per gallon with soap)
preventionTips: Mulch heavily to prevent soil splash onto leaves
Water at the base, never overhead
Provide good air circulation with proper spacing and pruning
Rotate nightshade crops on a 3-year cycle
Remove lower leaves that touch the soil

name: Late Blight
description: A devastating oomycete disease (Phytophthora infestans) that caused the Irish Potato Famine. Spreads rapidly in cool (60-70°F), wet conditions. Can destroy an entire crop in days.
symptoms: Large, water-soaked, grayish-green spots on leaves that quickly turn brown and papery, white fuzzy mold on leaf undersides in humid conditions, firm dark brown lesions on fruit, rapid plant death
organicTreatments: Remove and destroy infected plants immediately (do not compost)
preventionTips: Plant certified disease-free seed potatoes and transplants
Choose resistant varieties
Ensure excellent air circulation
Avoid overhead irrigation
Monitor weather forecasts and spray copper preventively before wet cool periods

name: Powdery Mildew
description: A fungal disease caused by various species that appears as a white powdery coating on leaf surfaces. Unlike most fungal diseases, it thrives in warm, dry conditions with cool nights. Does not require wet foliage.
symptoms: White or grayish powdery spots on upper leaf surfaces, spreading to cover entire leaves, leaf curling and distortion, yellowing and premature leaf drop, stunted growth, reduced fruit quality
organicTreatments: Milk spray (1 part milk to 9 parts water)
Baking soda spray (1 tbsp per gallon with drops of dish soap)
preventionTips: Plant resistant varieties
Space plants for good air circulation
Avoid overhead watering
Prune for airflow
Remove and destroy infected leaves early

name: Downy Mildew
description: An oomycete disease (not a true fungus) that thrives in cool, moist conditions with temperatures between 58-72°F. Spreads by wind-borne spores and through splashing water. Different species target different crops.
symptoms: Angular yellow or pale green spots on upper leaf surfaces bounded by veins, grayish-purple fuzzy growth on leaf undersides, rapid leaf browning and collapse, stunted growth
organicTreatments: Remove and destroy infected plant material
Improve air circulation by thinning plants
preventionTips: Provide excellent air circulation and spacing
Water early in the day at the base of plants
Choose resistant varieties
Avoid working among wet plants
Remove crop debris at season end

name: Blossom End Rot
description: A physiological disorder (not pathogenic) caused by calcium deficiency in developing fruit, usually triggered by inconsistent watering. The plant cannot transport calcium to the fruit fast enough during rapid growth.
symptoms: Dark, sunken, leathery patch on the blossom end (bottom) of fruit, usually appearing when fruit is half-grown, secondary mold may colonize affected area, primarily affects first fruits of the season
organicTreatments: Mulch heavily to retain soil moisture
Add calcium amendments (gypsum, bone meal) to soil before planting
Foliar calcium spray as a temporary measure
Remove affected fruit so plant can redirect energy
preventionTips: Maintain consistent soil moisture with mulch and regular watering
Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilizer which promotes rapid growth
Do not disturb roots by cultivating near plants
Test soil and amend with lime or gypsum if calcium is low
Use drip irrigation on a timer

name: Fusarium Wilt
description: A soilborne fungal disease (Fusarium oxysporum) that invades roots and blocks water-conducting vessels. Persists in soil for many years. Different races (strains) attack specific crops. Favored by warm soil temperatures.
symptoms: One-sided wilting of plant or individual branches, yellowing of lower leaves progressing upward, brown discoloration visible in cut stems (vascular browning), stunted growth, eventual plant death
organicTreatments: Remove and destroy infected plants (do not compost)
Solarize soil in heavily infested areas
Apply beneficial Trichoderma fungi to soil
Raise soil pH above 6.5 with lime
Use grafted plants onto resistant rootstock
preventionTips: Plant Fusarium-resistant varieties (F, FF, or FFF on seed packets)
Rotate crops on a 5-7 year cycle
Maintain soil pH of 6.5-7.0
Avoid moving soil from infested areas
Sterilize tools after working in infested beds

name: Verticillium Wilt
description: A soilborne fungal disease (Verticillium dahliae or V. albo-atrum) that invades roots and clogs the vascular system. Persists in soil for over a decade. Has an extremely wide host range of over 300 plant species.
symptoms: V-shaped yellowing at leaf margins, one-sided wilting of leaves or whole branches, lower leaves affected first and progressing upward, tan to brown vascular discoloration in cut stems, stunted growth
organicTreatments: Use grafted plants on resistant rootstock
preventionTips: Plant Verticillium-resistant varieties (V on seed packets)
Rotate with non-host crops (corn, grains, onions)
Avoid planting in recently infested soil
Maintain good soil health with compost
Do not overwater or over-fertilize with nitrogen

name: Damping Off
description: A complex of soilborne fungi (Pythium, Rhizoctonia, Fusarium) that attacks seeds and seedlings. Favored by cool, wet, poorly drained conditions. Most destructive to indoor-started seedlings and direct-sown seeds.
symptoms: Seeds fail to germinate (pre-emergence damping off), seedling stems become water-soaked and constricted at soil line, seedlings topple over and die, cottony white mold on soil surface, rapid seedling collapse
organicTreatments: Remove and discard affected seedlings and surrounding soil
preventionTips: Use sterile seed-starting mix
Ensure pots have good drainage
Do not overwater seedlings
Provide good air circulation with a small fan
Avoid sowing seeds too thickly
Bottom-water seedlings instead of overhead watering

name: Septoria Leaf Spot
description: A fungal disease (Septoria lycopersici) primarily affecting tomatoes. Spreads through splashing water and is favored by warm (68-77°F), wet, humid conditions. Overwinters in plant debris.
symptoms: Many small circular spots (1/8 inch) with dark brown borders and tan or gray centers on lower leaves first, tiny black fruiting bodies (pycnidia) visible in spot centers with a hand lens, extensive defoliation
organicTreatments: Copper fungicide spray on a regular schedule
Remove and destroy infected lower leaves
preventionTips: Mulch heavily to prevent soil splash
Water at the base, never overhead
Stake or cage plants to keep foliage off ground
Remove lower leaves up to first fruit cluster
Rotate tomatoes on a 3-year cycle

name: Bacterial Wilt
description: A bacterial disease (Ralstonia solanacearum for solanaceous crops, Erwinia tracheiphila for cucurbits) that clogs the vascular system. Cucurbit bacterial wilt is transmitted by cucumber beetles. Persists in soil.
symptoms: Sudden wilting of individual stems or entire plant without yellowing first, wilting does not recover overnight, sticky bacterial ooze visible when cut stem is placed in water, rapid plant death
organicTreatments: Remove and destroy infected plants immediately
Control cucumber beetles which transmit the disease to cucurbits
No chemical cure exists once plants are infected
preventionTips: Control cucumber beetles with row covers and traps
Plant wilt-resistant varieties
Remove infected plants immediately to prevent spread
Do not compost infected material
Rotate crops and avoid planting in previously infested soil

name: Anthracnose
description: A fungal disease caused by Colletotrichum species that affects many crops. Spreads through splashing water, infected seeds, and contaminated tools. Favored by warm, humid conditions.
symptoms: Sunken, dark, water-soaked spots on ripe fruit, concentric rings of spore-producing structures in lesions, salmon-pink or orange spore masses in wet weather, leaf spots and stem cankers
organicTreatments: Remove and destroy infected fruit and plant parts
preventionTips: Use certified disease-free seeds
Rotate crops on a 3-year cycle
Water at plant base, avoid overhead irrigation
Harvest fruit promptly when ripe
Clean up all crop debris at end of season

name: Mosaic Virus (TMV)
description: A viral disease (Tobacco Mosaic Virus and related viruses) that is extremely stable and easily transmitted by touch, tools, and contaminated tobacco products. Can persist on surfaces for years.
symptoms: Mottled light and dark green mosaic pattern on leaves, leaf curling and distortion, stunted plant growth, reduced fruit set, malformed fruit with uneven ripening, shoe-string leaves in severe cases
organicTreatments: No cure exists; remove and destroy infected plants
Disinfect tools and hands with milk solution (milk proteins deactivate TMV)
Control aphid vectors for other mosaic viruses
preventionTips: Plant TMV-resistant varieties (T on seed packets)
Wash hands thoroughly before handling plants
Do not use tobacco products near garden
Disinfect tools with 10% bleach or milk solution
Control aphids which spread other mosaic viruses

name: Black Rot
description: A bacterial disease (Xanthomonas campestris pv. campestris) that affects brassicas. Spreads through infected seed, splashing water, and contaminated tools. Can survive in crop debris for up to 2 years.
symptoms: V-shaped yellow lesions at leaf margins that expand inward, leaf veins turn black, affected areas become dry and papery, black discoloration of vascular tissue in stems, foul-smelling head rot
organicTreatments: Remove and destroy infected plants immediately
Hot water seed treatment (122°F for 20 minutes)
preventionTips: Use certified disease-free or hot water-treated seed
Rotate brassicas on a 3-year cycle
Avoid overhead irrigation
Do not work among wet plants
Remove and destroy crop debris after harvest

name: Club Root
description: A soilborne disease caused by the protist Plasmodiophora brassicae. Causes massive swelling of roots. Persists in soil for 15-20 years via resting spores. Favored by acidic, wet soils.
symptoms: Wilting on hot days despite adequate moisture, stunted and yellowed plants, swollen, distorted, club-shaped roots, reduced head formation, plants easily pulled from soil due to poor root function
organicTreatments: Raise soil pH to 7.2 or above with lime (strongly suppresses the pathogen)
Remove and destroy infected plants and root masses
preventionTips: Maintain soil pH above 7.0 with regular lime applications
Rotate brassicas on a 7+ year cycle in infested soil
Improve soil drainage
Do not move soil from infested areas
Start transplants in clean potting mix

name: Rust
description: A fungal disease caused by various Puccinia and Uromyces species. Named for the rust-colored pustules it produces. Many rust fungi are host-specific. Spreads by wind-borne spores and requires moisture on leaves.
symptoms: Orange, reddish-brown, or dark brown powdery pustules on leaf undersides, corresponding yellow spots on upper leaf surface, premature leaf drop, reduced plant vigor, stunted growth
preventionTips: Choose rust-resistant varieties
Space plants for good air circulation
Avoid overhead watering
Remove and destroy infected plant material
Clean up all debris at end of season

name: Botrytis (Gray Mold)
description: A fungal disease (Botrytis cinerea) that thrives in cool (60-75°F), humid conditions with poor air circulation. Attacks damaged, aging, or dead tissue first, then spreads to healthy tissue. Extremely wide host range.
symptoms: Gray fuzzy mold covering affected plant parts, water-soaked spots that quickly develop gray mold, blossom blight causing flowers to rot, fruit rot starting at stem end or wounds, stem cankers
organicTreatments: Remove and destroy all infected plant material
Improve air circulation by pruning and spacing
preventionTips: Space plants adequately for air circulation
Avoid overhead watering
Remove fading flowers and dead leaves promptly
Mulch to prevent soil contact with fruit
Harvest fruit promptly when ripe

name: White Mold (Sclerotinia)
description: A fungal disease (Sclerotinia sclerotiorum) that produces white cottony mycelium and hard black sclerotia (survival structures). These sclerotia can persist in soil for 5+ years. Favored by cool, moist conditions.
symptoms: White cottony fungal growth on stems, leaves, and fruit, water-soaked lesions that bleach and dry out, hard black sclerotia visible inside or on infected stems, wilting above the infection point, stem breakage
organicTreatments: Remove and destroy infected plants immediately
Apply Contans (Coniothyrium minitans) biological fungicide to soil
Deep burial of crop debris to prevent sclerotia germination
preventionTips: Rotate with non-host crops (corn, grains) for 3-4 years
Space plants for maximum air circulation
Avoid overhead watering
Promote rapid soil drying
Do not over-fertilize with nitrogen

name: Root Rot (Phytophthora)
description: A devastating oomycete disease (Phytophthora spp.) that thrives in waterlogged, poorly drained soils. Different species attack different crops. Zoospores swim through saturated soil to infect roots.
symptoms: Wilting despite adequate soil moisture, dark brown to black mushy roots, crown rot at soil line, stunted growth, yellowing and leaf drop, plant death, foul smell from decaying roots
organicTreatments: Remove infected plants and surrounding soil
Apply beneficial Trichoderma fungi to soil
preventionTips: Ensure excellent soil drainage
Use raised beds in heavy clay soils
Do not overwater
Avoid compacting soil around plants
Rotate crops and do not replant in infested areas for 3+ years

name: Bacterial Leaf Spot
description: A bacterial disease caused by Xanthomonas or Pseudomonas species. Spread by splashing water, infected seeds, and contaminated tools. Favored by warm, wet conditions. Multiple species target different crops.
symptoms: Small, dark, water-soaked spots on leaves that may develop yellow halos, spots may merge into larger necrotic areas, raised or scabby spots on fruit, premature defoliation, reduced yields
preventionTips: Use certified disease-free seed
Hot water seed treatment where appropriate
Avoid overhead irrigation
Rotate crops on a 2-3 year cycle
Do not save seed from infected crops

name: Alternaria Leaf Spot
description: A fungal disease caused by various Alternaria species. Creates distinctive concentric ring patterns (target spots) on leaves. Spreads through wind, rain, and contaminated seed. Favored by warm, humid conditions.
symptoms: Dark brown to black circular spots with concentric rings (target pattern) on leaves, spots may merge and cause large areas of dead tissue, yellowing around spots, premature defoliation, damping off in seedlings
organicTreatments: Improve air circulation by thinning plants
preventionTips: Use disease-free seed
Rotate crops on a 3-year cycle
Water at the base of plants
Maintain adequate plant nutrition
Remove crop debris at end of season
